abstract.shortdesc: Alternate text is a textual description of an image that can be read or displayed in place of the image. This is commonly used to create text alternatives for readers or systems that cannot view the original image.
Audio is recorded or reproduced sound.
Bold text is used to draw a reader's attention to a phrase without otherwise adding meaning to the content.
The body contains the main content of a topic.
Data is a generic component that represents metadata within a DITA topic or map. Complex metadata is represented by nested data structures.
The definition description provides the definition for a term in a definition list entry.
A description is a statement that describes or contains additional information about an object.
A definition list is a list of terms and corresponding definitions.
A definition list entry groups a term and its definition.
A definition term is the text that is defined in a definition list entry.
A figure is a container for a variety of objects, including artwork, images, code samples, equations, and tables.

The fn element specifies content for an ancillary note placed in the footer of a page or at the end of an online article. Such content is usually inappropriate for inline inclusion. The fn element also is used to indicate the source for facts or other material that is cited in the text.
Italic text is a way to emphasize the key points in printed text, or when quoting a speaker, a way to show which words the speaker stressed.
An image is a reference to artwork that is stored outside of the content.

The key definition convenience element provides a simple way to define a key without making the definition itself a part of rendered content. As with any key definition, the resource will still be rendered when the key is referenced.
A list item is an item in either an ordered or unordered list.
Link text is the label for a link or resource.
A DITA map is the mechanism for aggregating topics. It consists of references to topics, maps, and other resources; these references are organized into hierarchies, groups, and tables.

A navigation title provides a title for a resource. When used in topics, it is an alternate title that is designed for situations when the topic title is unsuitable for use in a table of contents or navigation pane. When used in maps, a navigation title can serve as an alternate title or simply as an aid to understanding the DITA map.
A note contains information that expands on or calls attention to a particular point.
An ordered list is a list of items that are sorted by sequence or order of importance.
A paragraph is a single unit of text that contains a main idea.

The ph element is used to enclose a phrase for reuse or conditional processing (for example, when part of a paragraph applies to a particular audience). It can be used by specializations of DITA to create semantic markup for content at the phrase level, which then allows (but does not require) specific processing or formatting.
Preformatted text is text that contains line breaks and spaces that are intended to be preserved at publication time.
The prolog contains metadata about the topic, for example, author information or subject category.
A section is an organizational division in a topic. Sections are used to organize subsets of information that are directly related to the topic; they can be titled.
A short description describes the purpose or main point of a topic.
Simple tables are tables that are regular in structure and do not need a caption.
A simple table entry represents a single cell within a simple table.
A simple table header is a header row for a simple table.
A simple table row is a single row in a simple table.
A subscript is text that is printed below the line. It is frequently used in chemical and mathematical formulas.
A superscript is text that is printed above the line. It is frequently used in chemical and mathematical formulas.
A title is a heading or label for an object. Titles can be associated with topics, maps, sections, examples, figures, tables, and other structures.
A topic is a standalone unit of information.
Topic metadata is metadata that applies to a topic; this metadata is defined in a map.

A topic reference is the mechanism for referencing a topic (or another resource) from a DITA map. It can nest, which enables the expression of navigation and table-of-content hierarchies, as well as containment hierarchies and parent-child relationships.
An underline, also called an underscore, is a line immediately below a portion of text.
An unordered list is a list in which the order of items is not significant.

A cross reference is an inline link. It can reference a different location within the current topic, another topic, a specific location in another topic, or an external resource such as a PDF or Web page.
